ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to analyze the ways in which plants interact with each other and the environment. I also learned about many mathematical models and theories for understanding ecology at many different scales. This course was more math-heavy than most E&EB classes, but the theory was always rooted in the real world.
Knowledge of ecology at various scales, processes that contribute to overarching themes
individual and community plant ecology, as well as ecosystem ecology and thinking on the biome scale.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: very interesting lectures from both Prof Staver and the guest lecturers, excellent class discussions, reasonable readings/workload (and the readings were interesting!), Prof Staver is generally a good professor and a fascinating scientist
Weaknesses: sometimes the themes felt disconnected because we would have a lot of guest lectures without much to tie them together; the journal entries often felt not very useful
I enjoyed having the guest lectures

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having the lectures recorded to review for problem sets and exams was helpful, and it was good to discuss concepts with others in breakout rooms. The format of psets and exams was also well-suited to the pandemic, and I enjoyed the weekly nature journals.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This is a fantastic course for upper level EEB students in particular, but I think anyone who took General Ecology and enjoyed the theoretical side of things would like this class a lot.
Yes, this is a good course to take for those interested in learning about ecology and connections between ecological concepts and issues such as climate change

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures were also recorded and available
